channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Using Adoptions, Russia Turns Ukrainian Children Into Spoils of War
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainian children have been transferred to Russia. “I didn’t want to go,” one girl told The New York Times from a foster home near Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: A broken window at a hospital in March in Mariupol, Ukraine. Russian officials have made clear that their goal is to replace any childhood attachment to home with a love for Russia.

item.title: Russia Hits Ukraine’s Power Infrastructure With Some of the Biggest Strikes in Recent Weeks
item.description: Ukrainian officials confirmed missile strikes in at least half a dozen regions, and the country’s state energy company imposed restrictions in several areas.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from part of an intercepted Russian missile in the center of Zaporizhzia, Ukraine, this week.

item.title: How Tumultuous Forces of Brexit Divided U.K.’s Conservative Party
item.description: Some experts link Liz Truss’s downfall to the ripple effect of Britain’s departure from the European Union and the bitter, ideologically opposed factions it created in her party.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brexit supporters gathering in front of a statue of Winston Churchill in London on Jan. 21, 2020, to celebrate Britain leaving the European Union.

item.title: Boris Johnson Gains Support for UK Prime Minister Bid
item.description: The former Conservative leader, who was forced out of office after scandals this summer, hasn’t declared his candidacy, but dozens of party lawmakers already support him.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Boris Johnson on Saturday at Gatwick Airport near London after returning from a vacation. While he was away, Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned.

item.title: How Trump Could Resist the Jan. 6 Panel’s Subpoena
item.description: If the ex-president turns down the drama of testifying, his legal team could mount several constitutional and procedural arguments in court.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team could also invoke executive privilege in an attempt to ward off the subpoena.

item.title: Voters Stick to Pandemic-Era Habits, As Early Turnout Surges
item.description: More than 5.5 million people have cast ballots in person or by mail. Experts predict high turnout in the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident drops off a mail-in ballot in Philadelphia.

item.title: Who Gets the Last Word on Steve Jobs? He Might.
item.description: When Laurene Powell Jobs unveiled a website dedicated to the story of her late husband, historians wondered if it could change how influential people burnish their legacies.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Jim Gensheimer/San Jose Mercury News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Steve Jobs spoke to the class of 2005 at Stanford. Material about Apple’s early years went to the university.

item.title: Lucy Simon, Singer and Broadway Composer, Dies at 82
item.description: She and her sister Carly Simon were a folk duo in the 1960s. Years later, she wrote the Tony-nominated music for “The Secret Garden.”
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Lucy Simon in 1982. Her younger sister, Carly, became a best-selling pop star after their folk-duo days, and her older sister, Joanna, was an opera singer. Joanna died a day before Lucy’s death.

item.title: Joanna Simon, Opera Singer from Famously Musical Family, Dies at 85
item.description: A renowned mezzo-soprano, she grew up alongside her younger sisters, Carly and Lucy, both of whom became singer-songwriters.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Carly and Lucy Simon on Music, Fame, Sibling Rivalry and, Yes, James Taylor
item.description: The sisters talk about “You’re So Vain,” a “Doctor Zhivago” connection and the moment Carly Simon fell in love with James Taylor.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes
item.media:credit: Ryan Conaty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucy Simon, left, and Carly Simon in Martha’s Vineyard, where they reflected on family life and their work.

item.title: Hu Jintao’s Departure Causes Stir as Xi Elevates Loyalists in Congress
item.description: A new lineup of the Communist Party elite will limit potential resistance to Mr. Xi’s agenda of bolstering security and expanding state sway over the economy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:credit: Noel Celis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Xi Jinping with Premier Li Keqiang, center, and the Politburo Standing Committee member Wang Yang during the closing ceremony of the party congress. Both Mr. Li and Mr. Wang stepped down from the Central Committee, indicating that both are set to retire.

item.title: Vulnerable and Trapped: A Look at Those Lost in Hurricane Ian
item.description: Ian slammed into Florida’s southwest coast last month. Its fearsome storm surge and torrential rain made it the deadliest storm in a generation.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Fawcett, Mitch Smith, Ava Sasani, Frances Robles and Eden Weingart
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peggy Collson’s home on the island of Matlacha had survived previous hurricanes, but it was destroyed by floodwaters from Ian.

item.title: Lab Manipulations of Covid Virus Fall Under Murky Government Rules
item.description: Mouse experiments at Boston University have spotlighted an ambiguous U.S. policy for research on potentially dangerous pathogens.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer and Benjamin Mueller
item.category: National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity

item.title: Among Seniors, a Declining Interest in Boosters
item.description: Americans over 65 remain the demographic most likely to have received the original series of vaccinations. But fewer are getting the follow-up shots, surveys indicate.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Christopher Occhicone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Saul Pashkoff rolled up his sleeve before receiving his second dose of the Covid-19 vaccine at a senior-care facility on Staten Island, N.Y.

item.title: Pickleball Is Expanding. Tennis Is Mad.
item.description: From New York to Hawaii, weekend athletes and government officials are taking part in a battle that goes beyond the fight for court space.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Guillem Casasus / Tennis court image by Getty Images

item.title: For New York Governor, The Times Endorses Kathy Hochul
item.description: In-person voting begins on Oct. 29.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Jingyu Lin for The New York Times

item.title: Not-So-Great Britain’s Conservative Crackup
item.description: Was Liz Truss a cat’s paw for a Boris Johnson comeback?
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: David Cliff/Associated Press

item.title: Biden Just Clobbered China’s Chip Industry
item.description: The latest American trade restrictions could significantly set back China’s semiconductor ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo
item.media:credit: Florence Lo/Reuters

item.title: Remote Work Is Here to Stay. Lean In, Employers.
item.description: A baby boomlet may not have been 2021’s only productivity increase.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Trauma Is the Best Comedy Material, but April 7 Was Not Funny
item.description: Comedy has helped me process the Israel-Palestine conflict. Then I was in a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: Noam Shuster Eliassi
item.media:credit: Ariel Schalit/Associated Press
item.media:description: The scene of a shooting attack in Tel Aviv on April 7.

item.title: Wonking Out: Facts, Feelings and Rural Politics
item.description: What explains small-town America’s sense of rage?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; photograph by Ed Freeman

item.title: Can Tim Ryan Pull Off the Biggest Upset of the Midterms in Ohio?
item.description: The Democrats are doing almost exactly what he said they should to save their political fortunes in the Midwest. But is it enough to win Ohio?
item.dc:creator: Alec MacGillis
item.media:credit: Megan Jelinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tim Ryan, the Democratic Senate nominee in Ohio, in Columbus this month. As manufacturing has declined in the state, so have Democratic fortunes.

item.title: Britain’s Troubles Are Teaching Us Something About Financial Markets
item.description: They have enormous influence over governments.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: Scare Tactics
item.description: It’s Halloween season, time for two-pound bags of fun-size candy and scary movies that haunt your dreams.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Encore: A Lifetime of Good Loving
item.description: After 56 years of marriage, a widow finds hope for the future by remembering the sweetness of life spent together.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Affordable Oysters and More Reader Requests
item.description: Looking for the best happy hour deals with quality food? We have recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Shukette in Chelsea, the Middle Eastern menu’s selection of oven-fired breads, richly spiced vegetables and seafood, and dips lends itself handsomely to group dining.

item.title: Your stories: Generational differences
item.description: We invited you to talk about your families and climate. Today, we’re sharing a few of the responses.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni

item.title: Appeals Court Temporarily Halts Biden’s Student Debt Cancellation
item.description: A federal appeals court on Friday temporarily halted President Biden’s student debt relief plan, preventing the government from moving forward with the debt cancellation it had said could start as early as next week.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden speaking about student loan forgiveness at Delaware State University on Friday in Dover.

item.title: Twitter Tries Calming Employees as Deal With Elon Musk Looms
item.description: With Mr. Musk’s $44 billion deal to buy Twitter set to close no later than Oct. 28, the company is trying to reassure workers about their employment and compensation.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. For months, the company’s 7,500 employees have worried how Elon Musk may change the service.

item.title: Twitch’s Relationship With Its Streamers Shows Its Cracks
item.description: The service recently said it was going to take a bigger cut of the money it shared with streamers. At an annual gathering in San Diego, they vented about the decision.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: John Francis Peters for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the recent TwitchCon in San Diego, streamers complained about changes the company has made.

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Alva Skog

item.title: How to Break a Phone Addiction
item.description: Whether smartphone overuse constitutes a true addiction is still up for debate, but experts say there are ways to scale down.
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: How to Prevent Memory Loss
item.description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.category: The Complete Guide to Memory: The Science of Strengthening Your Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mikyung Lee

item.title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Lower Back Pain
item.description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Cole Barash for The New York Times

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: How to Spend a Perfect Weekend in Santa Cruz
item.description: What once felt like a quirky California pit stop is now a popular getaway destination. Here’s a guide to the city’s beaches, bars, bookshops and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sloss
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the entrances to the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
